title.rendered: Recap: a look back at the 2021 Epsom Derby Festival

content.rendered:
Earlier this month, the Derby Festival took place at the picturesque Epsom Downs. The two-day meeting is home to three Group 1 races, and none more prestigious than the festival’s namesake, the Derby.

Racing fans and connections will now be gearing up for the next big meeting – Royal Ascot – which takes place this week. While you’re looking for the latest horse racing tips, let’s remind ourselves of the big winners at Epsom.

The Oaks: Snowfall

The third of five British Classics, the Oaks is only open to fillies, and it was Snowfall who handed trainer Aidan O’Brien yet another win in the race – his ninth victory since 1998. Frankie Dettori was in the saddle, as he rode Snowfall to a record 16-length victory, surpassing the previous record set by Sun Princess in 1983 – to also notch his sixth Oaks winner.

The Japanese-bred filly started off towards the rear of the pack, but Dettori powered on through the rain, taking the lead with just under two furlongs to go. It was an impressive finish that saw the duo push on and go clear in the final furlong. Stablemate Divinely finished in third, while the favourite, Santa Barbara,also from O’Brien’s yard could only finish fifth.

Coronation Cup: Pyledriver

There was a new winning trainer in the Coronation Cup, as William Muir & Chris Grassick’s Pyledriver won in what proved to be a thrilling race. Al Aasy was the pre-race favourite, and was denied in the closing stages, having held up in rear in the early stages, before going on to lead in the final furlong. A neck separated first from second, while Japan, trained by O’Brien finished in third, seven lengths behind.

It was a first Group 1 victory for Pyledriver with Martin Dwyer in the saddle. The jockey has now won all three of Epsom’s centrepiece races – his previous wins include the Oaks (Casual Look in 2003) and the Derby (Sir Percy in 2006). On completing the hat-trick of Group 1s at Epsom, Dwyer said;

“It’s special. If you’re not fashionable it’s hard to get good rides. Sometimes you feel you are defending yourself if you don’t win. Half my worry was losing the ride on him. When it comes right and you win a big race, you enjoy it that bit more. I’m very excited. He can only get better.”

The Derby: Adayar

There was a surprise win, as 16/1 shout Adayar won the Derby. Jockey, Adam Kirby had been scheduled to ride John Leeper, before Frankie Dettori was called up – and instead, Kirby was handed Adayar – replacing Oisin Murphy in the saddle.

But it was a move that appeared to pay off, as Kirby guided Adayar to victory by four and a half lengths over 50/1 chance Mojo Star in second, and Hurricane Lane in third. It’s not the first time that Kirby has defied the odds, having won at Royal Ascot last year, when riding Nando Parrado in the Group 2 Coventry Stakes – a rank outsider at 150/1.

And the jockey’s reaction at the finish line said it all:

“This is the Derby lads – get in there!”
